poetry

words.def: This list should include a description and a citation for each entry; you can help by expanding it. Descriptions without a citation may be deleted.

Noun used to describe the stress put on a certain syllable while speaking a word. Ex.- In Coleridge’s “Kubla Khan,” there has been much controversy over the pronunciation of “Abora” in line 41. According to Herbert Tucker of the website For Better For Verse, the accent is on the first and last syllable of the word, making its pronunciation: AborA.
words.name: Accent

words.def: Accentual verse is common in children's poetry; nursery rhymes and the less well-known skipping-rope rhymes are the most common form of accentual verse in the English Language.
words.name: Accentual verse

words.def: An acrostic is a poem or other form of writing in which the first letter, syllable or word of each line, paragraph or other recurring feature in the text spells out a word or a message.
words.name: Acrostic

words.def: a word or phrase which modifies a noun or pronoun, grammatically added to describe, identify, or quantify the related noun or pronoun.
words.name: Adjective

words.def: A describing word used to modify a verb, adjective, or another adverb. Typically ending in -ly, adverbs answer the questions when, how, and how many times.
words.name: Adverb

words.def: A specific type of writing in which the settings, characters, and events stand for other specific people, events, or ideas.
words.name: Allegory

words.def: Repetition of the initial sounds of words, as in “Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers”
words.name: Alliteration

words.def: A figure of speech that makes a reference to, or representation of, people, places, events, literary work, myths, or works of art, either directly or by implication.
words.name: Allusion

words.def: Erroneous use of an object, event, idea, or word that does not belong to that time period.
words.name: Anachronism

words.def: The point in a plot where a character recognizes the true state of affairs
words.name: Anagnorisis

words.def: An interjected scene that takes the narrative back in time from the current point the story has reached
words.name: Analepsis

words.def: Comparison between two things that are otherwise unlike. Ex. The dress is as white as snow.
words.name: Analogy

words.def: a version of the foot in poetry in which the first two syllables of a line are unstressed, followed by a stressed syllable. Ex. Intercept (the syllables in and ter are unstressed followed by cept which is stressed)
words.name: Anapest

words.def: a short account of a particular incident or event, especially of an interesting or amusing nature.
words.name: Anecdote

words.def: the adversary of the hero or protagonist of a drama or other literary work: Iago is the antagonist[16] of Othello.
words.name: Antagonist

words.def: A word or phrase referred to by any relative pronoun.
words.name: Antecedent

words.def: A figure of speech in which the speaker addresses an object, concept, or person (usually absent) that is unable to respond.
words.name: Apostrophe

words.def: stanzas having no particular pattern.
words.name: Astrophic

words.def: The omission of conjunctions between clauses. An example is when John F. Kennedy said on January the 20th 1961 "...that we shall pay any price, bear any burden, meet any hardship, support any friend, oppose any foe to assure the survival and the success of liberty."
words.name: Asyndeton

words.def: A piece describing one's development - such as a 'Coming-of-Age novel'
words.name: Bildungsroman

words.def: Verse written in iambic pentameter without rhyme.
words.name: Blank verse

words.def: When poetry is broken up by punctuation in the middle of lines
words.name: Caesura

words.def: Two lines with rhyming ends. Shakespeare often used a couplet to end a sonnet.
words.name: Couplet

words.def: School of haikai poetry founded by Nishiyama Sōin in 17th century Japan
words.name: Danrin school

words.def: A group of words containing a subject and a verb, but does not equate to a complete thought.
words.name: Dependent Clause

words.def: A work primarily featuring dialogue; a piece of, relating to, or written in dialogue.
words.name: Dialogic

words.def: Also known as "lexis" and "word choice," the term refers to the words selected for use in any oral, written, or literary expression. Diction often centers on opening a great array of lexical possibilities with the connotation of words by maintaining first the denotation of words.
words.name: Diction

words.def: Intended to teach, instruct, or have a moral lesson for the reader.
words.name: Didactic

words.def: A line of verse made up of two feet (two stresses).
words.name: Dimeter

words.def: Using ones senses as a medium for writing to relay emotion and the perception of sensations of oneself or of others and play upon those sensations to create a relatability stemming from the human condition.
words.name: Drama of sensibility

words.def: When the audience is aware of the plot or sections of the plot when the characters are not - such as in Romeo and Juliet when the audience is aware of Juliet's faking of her death and Romeo is unaware.
words.name: Dramatic irony

words.def: A vivid, graphic, or dramatic written commentary or description of another visual form of art.
words.name: Ekphrasis

words.def: A line in poetry that ends in a pause—indicated by a specific punctuation, such as a period or a semicolon.
words.name: End-stopped line

words.def: The continuing of a syntactic unit over the end of a line. Enjambment occurs when the sense of the line overflows the meter and line break.
words.name: Enjambment

words.def: A long poem that narrates the victories and adventures of a hero. It can be identified by lofty or elegant diction.
words.name: Epic poetry

words.def: A novel told through letters.
words.name: Epistolary novel

words.def: A rhyme with two syllables. One is stressed, one is unstressed. Examples: “Merry”, “Coffee”.
words.name: Feminine rhyme

words.def: An interjected scene that takes the narrative back in time from the current point the story has reached
words.name: Flashback

words.def: An interjected scene that takes the narrative forward in time from the current point of the story in literature, film, television and other media
words.name: Flashforward

words.def: Expresses a condition happening in the future by using shall, will, am, is, are and going to with a verb. Adverbs are also used with the present tense of the verb to show future tense.
words.name: Future

words.def: Prose written in a terse, haikai style, accompanied by haiku
words.name: Haibun

words.def: Broad genre comprising the related forms haiku haikai-renga and haibun
words.name: Haikai

words.def: Modern term for standalone hokku
words.name: Haiku

words.def: A line from a poem hat has six feet in its meter. Another name for hexameter is "The Alexandrine."
words.name: Hexameter

words.def: In Japanese poetry, the opening stanza of a renga or renku (haikai no renga)
words.name: Hokku

words.def: A term where different subordinate clauses are used in a sentence to qualify a single verb, or modify it.
words.name: Hypotactic

words.def: A word that’s tacked onto a sentence in order to add strong emotion. It’s grammatically unrelated to the rest of the sentence. They are usually followed by an exclamation point.
words.name: Interjection

words.def: Refers to the way in which different works of literature interact with and relate to one another in order to construct meaning.
words.name: Intertextuality

words.def: The use of one or more extra syllabic units (on) above the 5/7 standard in Japanese poetic forms such as waka and haiku.
words.name: Ji-amari

words.def: The use of fewer syllabic units (on) than the 5/7 standard in Japanese poetic forms such as waka and haiku.
words.name: Jitarazu

words.def: In Japanese poetry, a seasonal word or phrase required in haiku and renku
words.name: Kigo

words.def: In Japanese poetry, a "cutting word" required in haiku and hokku
words.name: Kireji

words.def: A short poem with a song-like quality, or designed to be set to music; often conveying feelings, emotions, or personal thoughts.
words.name: Lyric

words.def: A work that is characterized by extravagant theatricality and by the predominance of plot and physical action over characterization
words.name: Melodrama

words.def: Making a comparison between two unlike things without using the words like, as, or than.
words.name: Metaphor

words.def: A multi-lined strophic verse form which flourished in Islamic Spain in the 11th century, written in Arabic or Hebrew
words.name: Muwashshah

words.def: A theory or practice in literature emphasizing scientific observation of life without idealization and often including elements of determinism
words.name: Naturalism

words.def: The creation of new words, some arising from acronyms, word combinations, direct translations, and the addition of prefixes or suffixes.
words.name: Neologism

words.def: A genre of fiction that relies on narrative and possesses a considerable length, an expected complexity, and a sequential organization of action into story and plot distinctively. This genre is flexible in form, although prose is the standard, focuses around one or more characters, and is continuously reshaped and reformed by a speaker.
words.name: Novel

words.def: An eight line stanza of poetry.
words.name: Octet

words.def: A lyrical poem, sometimes sung, that focuses on the glorification of a single subject and its meaning. Often has an irregular stanza structure.
words.name: Ode

words.def: the formation of a word, as cuckoo, meow, honk, or boom, by imitation of a sound made by or associated with its referent.
words.name: Onomatopoeia

words.def: A verse form in which a stanza has eight iambic pentameter lines following the rhyme scheme abababcc. An ottava rima was often used for long narratives, especially epics and mock heroic poems.
words.name: Ottava rima

words.def: Combining of various syntactic units, usually prepositions, without the use of conjunctions to form short and simple phrases.
words.name: Paratactic

words.def: a verb tense that expresses an idea that something [in the past] occurred before another action [also in the past]. This tense [requires] the helping, or auxiliary word "had". For example, "you had studied French before you went to Paris."
words.name: Past Perfect

words.def: the grammatical form of a verb used to indicate that the time of the action occurred before the moment of writing.
words.name: Past Tense

words.def: A work depicting an idealized vision of the rural life of shepherds.
words.name: Pastoral

words.def: In poetry, a line of verse containing five metric feet or accents.
words.name: Pentameter

words.def: A sequence of two or more words, forming a unit.In the poem “Kubla Khan” by Samuel Coleridge, the words “pleasure-dome” is a phrase read not only in this poem, but also in Mary Shelley’s “Frankenstein” when she uses also uses the phrase.
words.name: Phrase

words.def: A verb tense that describes actions just finished or continuing from the past into the present. This can also imply that past actions have present effects.
words.name: Present Perfect

words.def: An interjected scene that takes the narrative forward in time from the current point of the story in literature, film, television and other media
words.name: Prolepsis

words.def: Can be used in place of a noun or, in some cases, another pronoun.
words.name: Pronoun

words.def: A stanza of four lines.
words.name: Quatrain

words.def: A stanza of five lines.
words.name: Quintain

words.def: A genre of Japanese collaborative poetry
words.name: Renga

words.def: In Japanese poetry, a form of popular collaborative linked verse formerly known as haikai no renga, or haikai
words.name: Renku

words.def: A form of collaborative poetry pioneered by Makoto Ooka in Japan in the 1980s
words.name: Renshi

words.def: A measured pattern of words and phrases arranged by sound, time, or events. These patterns are [created] in verse or prose by use of stressed and unstressed syllables.
words.name: Rhythm

words.def: A form of poem consisting of three quatrains ending with a rhyming couplet.
words.name: Shakespearean sonnet

words.def: A comparison of two different things that utilizes “like” or “as”.
words.name: Simile

words.def: A 14 line poem written in iambic pentameter. There are two types of sonnets: Shakespearean and Italian. The Shakespearean sonnet is written with 3 quatrain and a couplet in abab, cdcd, efef, gg rhythmic pattern. An Italian sonnet is written in 2 stanzas with an octave followed by a septet in abba, abba, cdecde or cdcdcd rhythmic pattern.
words.name: Sonnet

words.def: A foot consisting of two syllables of approximately equal stress.
words.name: Spondee

words.def: Group of lines offset by a space and then continuing with the next group of lines with a set pattern or number of lines.
words.name: Stanza

words.def: Adjective describing poetry with lines of the same meter and length throughout, but not organized into regular stanzas. Example: Form of Samuel Taylor Coleridge's "Frost at Midnight"
words.name: Stichic

words.def: Subjunctive forms of verbs are typically used to express various states of unreality such as wish, emotion, possibility, judgment, opinion, necessity, or action that has not yet occurred. Subjunctive verbs are often found in "that" clauses. The verb requires "that" to follow it e.g. 'He insisted that was the wrong way'.
words.name: Subjunctive

words.def: Adjective meaning an immeasurable experience, unable to be rationalized.
words.name: Sublime

words.def: A term where an entire idea is expressed by something smaller, such as a phrase or a single word; one part of the idea expresses the whole. This concept can also be reversed.
words.name: Synecdoche

words.def: The study of how words are arranged in a sentence. Ex.- Line 68 of Coleridge’s “Dejection: An Ode,” is difficult to determine its syntax because of the way the words are arranged: “Which wedding Nature to us gives in dower.” The word “wedding” could be seen as a verb or a noun.
words.name: Syntax

words.def: In Japanese poetry, a short poem in the form 5,7,5,7,7 syllabic units
words.name: Tanka

words.def: In Japanese poetry, a tanka where the upper part is composed by one poet, and the lower part by another
words.name: Tan-renga

words.def: A telestich is a poem or other form of writing in which the last letter, syllable or word of each line, paragraph or other recurring feature in the text spells out a word or a message.
words.name: Telestich

words.def: In Occitan lyric poetry, a final, shorter stanza (cobla), addressed to a patron, lady, or friend
words.name: Tornada

words.def: A figurative or metaphorical use of a word or expression (a figure of speech). Example: "I'll die of embarrassment" or "She has tons of money".
words.name: Trope (literature)

words.def: A turn or switch that emphasizes a change in ideas or emotions. It can be marked by the words “but” or “yet.” In a sonnet, this change separates the octave from the sestet.
words.name: Volta

words.def: The use of informal, common speech, particularly of uneducated people. Similar to the use of vernacular.
words.name: Vulgate

words.def: A pseudo-archaic form of diction affected by some writers, particularly those of historical fiction.
words.name: Wardour Street English

words.def: The site of a renga session; also, the sense of dialogue and community present in such a session
words.name: Za
